Boyd preached from Jeremiah 4:14. “O Jerusalem, wash thy heart from wickedness, that thou mayest be saved:[”] (how long shall thy vain thoughts lodge within thee?—omitted) repentance again— The calls are as frequent as they are fruitless— I had had received last Sunday evening a note from Mrs Stewart in behalf of her mother Mrs Tudor requesting me to call on them the next Morning or when I might find it convenient— I went there from Church— The purpose of Mrs Stewart was to prevail upon me to present in the House a petition from Mrs Tudor for the allowance of an outfit of a Charge d’Affaires, to Mrs Tudor as William Tudor, junrs. mother for his services while Consul at Lima in Peru; during the time when he was acting in the absence of Mr Prevost as a diplomatic agent— As I wrote and introduced and carried through her former petition for an allowance on the same account, I had advised her to have her new petition first presented in the Senate; but she has found no member of that body willing to undertake that service for her; and W. R. King of Alabama told me some days since that the only chance of success for her in the Senate would be that a bill should first come from the House— After some hesitation I finally took the commendatory Letters, and said I would converse with Mr Caleb Cushing a member of the Committee of foreign Affairs of the House, to ascertain if there was a probability of obtaining a favourable report upon this claim from that Committee— At home I had hoped to find time this day for writing something on the Smithsonian fund Bill report, but was disappointed— Hours were consumed in assorting, filing and endorsing the Letters that I receive—chiefly trash;—I receive an average of one pamphlet every day; and scarcely ever have to read one of them— This day however I read a pamphlet with the singular title of Remarks upon Mr Binney’s Letter of January 3 1840 to the Presidents of the Councils of the City of Philadelphia—by the writer of the Letter— He refused to take depretiated bank paper in payment of a debt from the City of Philadelphia to him; and found it necessary to publish this pamphlet in his own justification— It is admirably well written, and appears to have brought the City Councils of Philadelphia to the just sense of their obligations.

The morning slip’d away till near 11. O’Clock before I recollected that it was the day for the semi-weekly meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— I then hurried up to the capitol and at a quarter past 11. arrived just in time to make a Quorum—three other members afterwards came in and there were present Slade, Tillinghast, Dromgoole, Worthington, Mitchell, Eastman and Davis— Absent only Nisbet.— Walking to the Capitol I met judge Wayne of the U.S. Supreme Court now in Session, as he came out from his lodgings, who told me, that on Saturday, Cornelius P. Van Ness, had delivered a very able argument in the Holmes case; against the power of a Governor of a State to deliver up a criminal at the demand of a foreign Government— There was no argument on the other side— In the Committee of manufactures, all the subjects before the Committee were postponed to the next Meeting, but the Chairman was authorised to confer with the Secretary, upon the complaints of frauds practiced in the collection of the revenue, charged in sundry memorials from woolen manufacturers, referred by the House to the Committee— In the House, W. Cost Johnson had the floor upon my amendment to Waddy Thompson’s resolution concerning the receipt of petitions— He yielded it to John W Jones, to report the civil and diplomatic appropriation bill—with a motion that the Clerk be authorised to contract for the printing of the Bills, and accompanying documents, upon the terms of the joint resolution of 1819.— Giddings of Ohio, offered as an amendment and substitute that until the further order of the House, the printing should be given to the lowest bidder— And now began a series of manoeuvering, I scarce can say whether most diverting or disgusting.— Giddings’s amendment was carried by yeas and naysto 65. and in the face of such a majority, Duncan of Ohio, immediately moved a reconsideration— He was in favour of giving the printing to the lowest bidder but not now.— He made a Speech to muster up paltry objections, and then moved the previous question to cut off all reply.— There was a decision of the Speaker against a call of the house, reversed by yeas and nays,tothen a call of the house—previous question— Motion to lay the whole subject on the table—lost by a vote of 108 to 110.— And at last the Resolution as amended by Giddings carried by yeas and nays 115 to 97. whereupon John W. Davis immediately moved a reconsideration— It was found impossible through all this writhing, twisting and coiling, to rally the entire Kinderhoek party against Giddings’s lowest bidder—but they will reverse it to-morrow. Pickens, Griffin and Charles Shepard stood firm through all the votes, and they defeated the whole Kinderhoek host. The rest of the South-Carolina nullifiers flinched, and skulked;—especially Holmes the pure—the immaculate— These operations consumed more than three hours; after which W. Cost Johnson resumed the floor, spoke about an hour more of his Anti-abolition discourse, and had not finished when the house adjourned I went into the library to find the date of the Piracy in the Schooner Plattsburg. 1817.

Mrs Telfair came this morning, and expressed her fears that the Committee on Revolutionary claims would report unfavourably to the claim of her Sister and herself— She complained of unkindness and inconsistency from Mr Taliaferro, and said Mr Hiland Hall whom they had visited yesterday, had told them it was useless for them to remain any longer here— It is certain that I can do nothing for them, and the weight of Evidence is against their claim. I called on the Secretary of the Treasury, and told him that sundry memorials from woollen manufacturers, complaining of frauds injurious to them in the collection of the revenue had been referred by the house to the Committee of Manufactures, who had directed me to see him and enquire if he had any information upon the subject, from the Collectors, which might be useful to the Committee in their enquiries— He said there was much complaint from the Collectors, not only of undervalued invoices, but of judicial constructions, and verdicts of juries, against the Government, of which he gave me several instances—chiefly with regard to silks—and which he said he would communicate to me in documentary form. Thence I went to the Department of State; where the Secretary Forsyth not being there, I saw the chief Clerk Aaron Vail—and found some of the correspondence respecting the Pirates and murderers of the Schooner Plattsburg, particularly a Letter from me to A. Gallatin of 11. November 1837—but I had not time to examine the whole correspondence— I told Vail, I should probably offer a Resolution for a call— Going to the House, I met in the Capitol Yard Daniel Webster, and greeted him upon his recent return from his visit to England— I found the House in Session, and W. Cost Johnson, upon the floor concluding his anti-abolition Speech, which took him between two or three hours.— He was about half tipsey, and in his merriest and wittiest mood— In undertaking to answer my last speech, he took the course under the form of nauseous and fetid flattery, to make me as ridiculous before the house and the country, as he possibly could— He closed with offering a resolution as an amendment to mine, providing that no petition resolution or paper relating to slavery or the abolition of Slavery or the Slave trade in any State, District, or Territory should be received or in any manner entertained by the House— I objected to this as not in order, my own resolution being an amendment to an amendment, beyond which in the uniform practice of the house are inadmissible— But Thompson accepted Johnson’s Resolution as an addition to his own, and Linn Banks who had been put by the Speaker into his chair expressly for the occasion declared the combined Resolutions in order;—Vanderpoel made a short and furious Speech which he closed by calling the previous question the main question was on the combined Resolutions, carried by yeas and nays 116 to 106. and then carried as amended 114 to 108—and thus it is made a rule of the house that no abolition petitions shall be received— Davis of Indiana then moved a reconsideration of the resolution adopted yesterday about the printing— Carried—

Morning visits from John G. Whittier, Isaac Winslow, and Samuel Mifflin, all of the Society of Friends and all abolitionists— Whittier is now the Editor of the Pennsylvania Freemason Newspaper, published weekly at Philadelphia— Whittier said he thought this last outrage upon the right of Petition, the establishment of a rule refusing to receive or entertain any abolition petition, might perhaps be the best thing that could have been done to promote the cause of abolition— It was at last casting off all disguise. I said it would depend upon the impression which it would make on the people; and I had little expectation from that.— They had been familiarized to the privation of the right, and could not be roused to take an interest in it— The difference between the Resolutions of the four preceding Sessions of Congress, and the new rule of the house, is the difference between petty larceny and highway robbery.— I had much conversation with these men, upon the dissensions among the anti-slavery men, and abolitionists, and concerning the late Benjamin Lundy. At the House W. Parmenter asked leave to present a petition of sundry citizens of the 6th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, contesting the right of Osmyn Baker to a seat in the House, which he took a few days since; but there was a point of order pending, upon an appeal by Jameson of Missouri from a decision of the Speaker last Evening.— Davis of Indiana, had moved a reconsideration of the vote of the preceding day, to have the printing done by the lowest bidder; for the purpose of offering resolutions of his own; the first of which was to proceed immediately to the election of a printer; and then for a Committee of 5 to be appointed by the House to examine and report how the printing shall be done hereafter. The vote of the former day was reconsidered.— But Graves got the floor; before Davis and offered a Resolution of his own; to which he allowed Rice Garland to offer an amendment—so as to have precedence for consideration before Davis’s proposition— Jameson’s point was, that Davis’s motion for reconsideration having been made for the declared purpose of offering a specific resolution, he was entitled to the floor in preference to all others to offer his resolution— Against this the Speaker decided, and after a long trifling and ridiculous debate his decision was sustained 126 to 71— Graves then made a long speech in support of his proposition, and cited the editorial Article in the Globe warning the Administration party that the paper cannot be sustained, if deprived of the profits of the public printing— The day was consumed in this wretched altercation without advancing one step in business— Stanly got entangled in some cutting remark that he made offensive to Smith of Maine, for which he was called to order, and a debate was got up whether he should be allowed to proceed; in the midst of which the house about four O’Clock adjourned.—There has been no more disorderly day during the Session, and the condition of the House is such as I never before witnessed—

This Mr Farnsworth had some days since written me a Letter, proposing to travel in Europe for the benefit of the Smithsonian Institution— He came this morning to see me with the same purpose— He is a native of New-England—has been President of some College in the Western Country, which from ill health he has been obliged to leave, and he is now wandering about the world in the pursuit of health.— Of the speculators of the Smithsonian fund he is one among the most needy, and it was with some reluctance that I told him that I thought there would be no occasion for a traveller for the Smithsonian fund at least for the present— Commodore Isaac Chauncey, President of the board of Navy Commissioners, died last Monday, and his funeral was announced for this morning at 11. O’Clock.— It was the hour for the Meeting of the Committee of manufactures, but there was nothing of importance upon which they could now act, and I attended the funeral, as a testimonial of respect to a gallant Officer who had served his Country in War, and to whom I was indebted for acts of personal kindness never to be forgotten— The funeral ceremonies were with military and naval honours—a considerable concourse of People—three uniformed companies of the District Militia— The President, and four heads of Departments were there—Generals Macomb and Scott with many other army Officers in full uniform— Commodore Morris superintended the arrangements— President Van Buren offered me a seat in his Chariot which I accepted.— It was past noon when the procession left the house for the Eastern branch graveyard— My conversation with the President was about Edward Everett and Marcus Morton; the past and present Governors of Massachusetts; and about Banks and Banking; points upon which, there was no difference of opinion, except with regard to the remedy for the evil, between us— After passing by the Capitol yard, on the way to the cemetery, the Carriage turned out from the procession, and entering the yard at the Northern gate set me down under the arch beside the door leading to the Hall of the House of Representatives. It was one O’Clock— The House had been an hour in Session— I found the doors of the Hall closed upon a Call of the House, on a motion of Davis of Indiana, to lay on the table the Resolutions of Graves and Rice Garland about the printing— My name had been noted as absent, and I had been excused— I was soon admitted into the Hall— Further proceedings in the call were superseded— The Resolutions of Graves and Garland were laid on the table by a vote of 116 to 108. and after much altercation and chicanery. The Printers were chosen viva voce— Blair and Rives 110. Gales and Seaton 92. Scattering 5. whole number voting 207. Blair and Rives chosen— The house adjourned at 7. P.M— Thomas Dumphy was in waiting for me; and I walked home with him, in darkness.

Morning visit from Mr Radcliff, with two new Memorials praying for the aid of the Government of the United States, in procuring the construction of a ship canal across the isthmus between North and South-America, which he wished me to present to the House, and to have referred to a select Committee of which I should be chairman— He brought and left with me the report of C. F. Mercer, chairman of the Committee on roads and Canals made on the 2d. of March 1839.—(Report No. 322. H.R.U.S— 25th. Congress 3d Session) upon a similar memorial formerly in Jany 1838 presented by me— The Report closes with a Resolution requesting the President to consider the expediency of further negotiating to ascertain the practicability of opening a ship canal communication between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans— This Resolution was adopted by the House, but Mr Radcliff says the President declines doing any thing without an appropriation— I told Mr Radcliff that if he wished the memorials to succeed, it would be better to have them referred to the Committee of Roads and Canals, than to a select Committee. I said too that I was so overwhelmed with other indispensable business that it would be impossible for me as Chairman of a select Committee to do justice to this— I said further that I thought he could not get a better Chairman than Charles Ogle the present Chairman of the Committee of Roads and Canals. He said it would perhaps be advisable to have these Memorials first presented in the Senate. I thought it would; and I advised him to have it presented by a friend of the administration— After naming several, he finally fixed upon Dr Linn of Missouri; which I approved— At the house, after an ineffectual attempt of Davies of Pennsylvania, to proceed to the election of a chaplain, and the annunciation by Graves of a sort of bargain that the Committee of five to devise the cheapest mode of printing, should consist of Black, the mover of the Resolution as Chairman and two of each party as members, which was disclaimed as a bargain on the other side, a call of the house ensued— A motion was carried that the election should be made viva voce— Turney moved that the choice should be made, one by one—this was rejected by yeas and naystoThe roll was called alphabetically, and each member named five for whom he voted to constitute the Committee— I voted for Black, Bond, Petrikin, Fillmore and Briggs— Hopkins of Virginia made a very foolish speech, asking to be excused from voting— The House refused to excuse him— He said he would then excuse himself, and did not vote— James Monroe declined voting, saying he looked upon the whole transaction as a humbug— So did I— But it is not wise to set the house at defiance upon small points— Three hours and more were consumed in taking the vote, and it would have taken as many more to count and sort the votes— The Clock had Struck 4—and after a protracted and tumultuous struggle the House adjourned over to Monday— Evening visit from Mr Lawrence.
